articles.headline: Woman Recounts Quarrel Leading to Agent Scandal
articles.snippet: A dispute over what a Secret Service agent owed a Colombian woman working as a high-priced escort led to a scandal that has now prompted the exit of three employees from the agency.
articles.abstract: A dispute over what a Secret Service agent owed a Colombian woman working as a high-priced escort led to a scandal that has now prompted the exit of three employees from the agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARTAGENA, Colombia — A Secret Service agent preparing for President Obama’s arrival at an international summit meeting and a single mother from Colombia who makes a living as a high-priced escort faced off in a room at the Hotel Caribe a week ago over how much he owed her for the previous night’s intercourse. “I tell him, ‘Baby, my cash money,’ ” the woman said in her first public comments on a dispute that would soon spiral into a full-blown scandal.
articles.byline: By William Neuman and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: In Spain, Euro Rescue Fund May Face Its Biggest Test
articles.snippet: Concern over the health of Spain’s banks has fueled speculation that, for the first time, the bailout fund might be needed to help recapitalize the financial institutions of a big country.
articles.abstract: Concern over the health of Spain’s banks has fueled speculation that, for the first time, the bailout fund might be needed to help recapitalize the financial institutions of a big country.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG — The euro zone’s rescue fund has already helped mount full-scale bailouts of three of Europe’s smaller economies.

articles.headline: In Wariness on Economy, Poll Finds Opening for Romney
articles.snippet: Americans see the economy improving, but doubts about their own financial circumstances may help Mitt Romney’s campaign, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: Americans see the economy improving, but doubts about their own financial circumstances may help Mitt Romney’s campaign, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: A rising number of Americans see improvement in the economy, but a persistent wariness about their own financial circumstances is allowing Mitt Romney to persuade voters that he could improve their economic prospects more than President Obama, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Allison Kopicki

articles.headline: In a Shift, Medicare Pushes Bids
articles.snippet: The Obama administration said it would widen the use of competitive bidding to buy equipment for Medicare beneficiaries because a pilot program saved money without harming care.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration said it would widen the use of competitive bidding to buy equipment for Medicare beneficiaries because a pilot program saved money without harming care.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Wednesday that it would vastly expand the use of competitive bidding to buy medical equipment for Medicare beneficiaries after a one-year experiment saved money for taxpayers and patients without harming the quality of care.

articles.headline: In Ohio, Hurdles for Both Candidates
articles.snippet: More than half of the state’s electorate is white and working class, a group that President Obama and Mitt Romney have each had a hard time connecting with.
articles.abstract: More than half of the state’s electorate is white and working class, a group that President Obama and Mitt Romney have each had a hard time connecting with.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELYRIA, Ohio — The battle for Ohio is on, but for many voters here choosing between President Obama and Mitt Romney is like trying to decide between liver and brussels sprouts — a selection they would rather not have to make.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Signs of an Asian Arms Buildup in India’s Missile Test
articles.snippet: With the launching of the missile, called the Agni 5, India joins a small group of countries with long-range nuclear missile capability, including China, Britain, France, Russia, Israel and the United States.
articles.abstract: With the launching of the missile, called the Agni 5, India joins a small group of countries with long-range nuclear missile capability, including China, Britain, France, Russia, Israel and the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s successful test on Thursday of a long-range ballistic missile capable of carrying a nuclear warhead is the latest escalation of an arms race in Asia, where the assertiveness and rising military power of China has rattled the region and prompted a forceful response from the Obama administration.
articles.byline: By Heather Timmons and Jim Yardley

articles.headline: Nokia Posts $1.2 Billion Loss as Phone Sales Tumble
articles.snippet: Nokia, which is trying to mount a comeback with Microsoft Windows phones, saw demand for its old Symbian phones — and its profit — plunge in the first quarter.
articles.abstract: Nokia, which is trying to mount a comeback with Microsoft Windows phones, saw demand for its old Symbian phones — and its profit — plunge in the first quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nokia, struggling to reinvent its smartphone business around Microsoft’s Windows Phone software, said Thursday that it might have to cut prices of its cheaper Lumia models to keep its new phones competitive in some markets.

articles.headline: India Struggles to Deliver Enough Power
articles.snippet: India cannot get enough fuel to run power plants, and the problem has contributed significantly to a second year of slowing economic growth in the country.
articles.abstract: India cannot get enough fuel to run power plants, and the problem has contributed significantly to a second year of slowing economic growth in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: NELLORE, India — India has long struggled to provide enough electricity to light its homes and power its industry around the clock. In recent years, the government and private sector sought to change that by building scores of new power plants.
